Continuous Water Quality Report

Introduction

The Department of Water Resources (DWR) and the US Bureau of Reclamation (USBR) are required by Water Right Decision 1641 (D-1641) to collect continuous water chemistry data to monitor the water quality at select sites in the upper San Francisco Estuary (Estuary). This report describes the results of these monitoring efforts for water year 2023 (October 1st 2022 through September 30th 2023), which was classified as a wet year in the Sacramento Valley (source). Results are compared to the previous water year, which was classified as a critically dry year.

Methods

Discrete water quality samples were collected monthly at 24 monitoring sites throughout the Upper Estuary and were grouped into regions based on their geographic location . These sites represent a variety of aquatic habitats, from narrow, freshwater channels to broad, estuarine bays.

Water quality data was continuously monitored at 15 sites throughout the Upper Estuary and were grouped into regions based on their geographic location (Figure 1; Table 1). These sites represent a variety of aquatic habitats, from narrow, freshwater channels to broad, estuarine bays. Note: CEMP’s Sherman Island station (SSI), which was called D11A in previous reports, has been renamed D22A to better reflect it’s location in relation to historical station D22.

Table 1: test
Region Stations
Northern Interior Delta C3A and NZ068
Southern Interior Delta C9, C10A, MD10A and P8
Central Delta D16, D19, D26 and D28A
The Confluence D4, D10, D12 and D22
Grizzly and Suisun Bay D7, D8, NZ032 and NZS42
San Pablo Bay D6, D41, D41A, NZ002, NZ004 and NZ325

Data were collected for six water quality parameters. All water samples were collected 1-meter below the water surface using a float-mounted YSI EXO2 multi-parameter water quality sonde. These parameters are:

  • Water Temperature (°C)
  • Specific Conductance (μS/cm)
  • Dissolved Oxygen (mg/L)
  • pH
  • Turbidity (FNU)
  • Fluorescence (μg/L)

Regional facet graphs were created for each parameter. The average, minimum, and maximum values were determined for parameter, both overall and per region. Average summary statistics are reported as the mean (μ) ± the standard deviation.

For more in-depth methodology, see here.

Results

Water Temperature

The average water temperature value was 13.96 ± 4.23 °C; for comparison, the previous year average was 18.03 ± 5.11 °C. Values ranged from 7.729104167 °C to 23.60645833 °C. Per region average, minimum, and maximum values are shown in Table 2; time series plots are shown in Figure y.

Table 2: test
Statistic Central Delta Confluence Northern Interior Delta Southern Interior Delta Suisun & Grizzly Bay
Average 14.20 14.12 13.76 13.85 13.85
Min 8.30 8.78 7.95 7.73 8.86
Max 21.91 20.83 21.94 23.61 20.21

Specific Conductance

The average water temperature value was 7393.65 ± 8987.78 μS/cm; for comparison, the previous year average was 5469.44 ± 7802.69 μS/cm. Values ranged from 73.63541667 μS/cm to 31598.125 μS/cm. Per region average, minimum, and maximum values are shown in Table 3; time series plots are shown in Figure y.

Table 3: test
Statistic Central Delta Confluence Northern Interior Delta Southern Interior Delta Suisun & Grizzly Bay
Average 861.90 8217.48 294.14 427.44 20514.45
Min 402.06 1008.84 128.42 73.64 9377.93
Max 2078.92 17901.52 1509.46 820.16 31598.12

Dissolved Oxygen

The average water temperature value was 9.22 ± 0.91 mg/L; for comparison, the previous year average was 8.97 ± 1.14 mg/L. Values ranged from 5.859479167 mg/L to 11.99833333 mg/L. Per region average, minimum, and maximum values are shown in Table 4; time series plots are shown in Figure y.

Table 4: test
Statistic Central Delta Confluence Northern Interior Delta Southern Interior Delta Suisun & Grizzly Bay
Average 9.59 9.32 9.81 8.74 8.94
Min 8.34 8.10 8.33 5.86 7.57
Max 12.00 10.69 11.01 11.29 10.27

Stockton Station DO Values

C-EMP monitors DO values at the Stockton Ship channel <etc etc>. The range of monthly DO values at the Stockton station is shown below. The monthly average DO levels at the Stockton station did not fall below the 5.0 mg/L standard set by the CVRWQCB (1998) for the December - August period. The monthly average DO levels dropped below the 6.0 mg/L standard (SWRCB, 1995) during the passage of fall-run Chinook salmon through the ship channel in September and October for the September - November control period.

pH

The average water temperature value was 7.76 ± 0.23 test; for comparison, the previous year average was 7.87 ± 0.32 test. Values ranged from 6.902083333 test to 9.376458333 test. Per region average, minimum, and maximum values are shown in Table 5; time series plots are shown in Figure y.

Table 5: test
Statistic Central Delta Confluence Northern Interior Delta Southern Interior Delta Suisun & Grizzly Bay
Average 7.85 7.80 7.73 7.51 7.88
Min 7.46 7.55 7.38 6.90 7.76
Max 9.38 7.99 7.93 7.81 8.07

Turbidity

The average water temperature value was 11.09 ± 10.61 FNU; for comparison, the previous year average was 14.73 ± 16.5 FNU. Values ranged from 0.195729167 FNU to 129.146875 FNU. Per region average, minimum, and maximum values are shown in Table 6; time series plots are shown in Figure y.

Table 6: test
Statistic Central Delta Confluence Northern Interior Delta Southern Interior Delta Suisun & Grizzly Bay
Average 4.21 12.04 6.41 4.55 22.85
Min 0.20 5.60 0.82 0.93 7.12
Max 20.33 29.18 129.15 34.87 99.59

Chlorophyll a Fluorescence

The average water temperature value was 1.96 ± 0.9 μg/L; for comparison, the previous year average was 2.86 ± 1.76 μg/L. Values ranged from 0.335104167 μg/L to 9.604583333 μg/L. Per region average, minimum, and maximum values are shown in Table 7; time series plots are shown in Figure y.

Table 7: test
Statistic Central Delta Confluence Northern Interior Delta Southern Interior Delta Suisun & Grizzly Bay
Average 2.14 1.60 1.61 2.15 2.15
Min 0.92 0.57 0.43 0.34 0.40
Max 4.54 4.48 6.30 9.60 4.89

References

[CVRWQCB] Central Valley Regional Water Quality Control Board. (1998). Water Quality Control Plan for the California Regional Water Quality Control Board Central Valley Region, the Sacramento River Basin, and San Joaquin River Basin [Basin Plan] (4th ed.).

[SWRCB] State Water Resources Control Board. (1999). Water Rights Decision 1641 for the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta and Suisun Marsh (Adopted December 29, 1999, Revised in Accordance with order WR2000-02 March 15, 2000). Sacramento, CA.
